abstract.p: In n-point osculatory interpolation of order r<sub>i</sub> - 1 at points x<sub>i</sub>, i = 1, 2, ⋯, n, by a rational expression N(x)/D(x), where N(x) and D(x) are polynomials ∑ a<sub>jx</sub><sup>j</sup> and ∑ b<sub>jx</sub><sup>j</sup>, we use the lemma that the system (1) {N(x<sub>i</sub>)/D(x<sub>i</sub>)}<sup>(m)</sup> = f<sup>(m)</sup> (x<sub>i</sub>), m = 0, 1,⋯,r<sub>i</sub> - 1, is equivalent to (2) N<sup>(m)</sup>(x<sub>i</sub>) = {f(x<sub>i</sub>)D(x<sub>i</sub>)}<sup>(m)</sup>, m = 0, 1, ⋯, r<sub>i</sub> - 1, D(x<sub>i</sub>) ≠ 0. This equivalence does not require N(x) or D(x) to be a polynomial or even a linear combination of given functions. The lemma implies that (1), superficially non-linear in a<sub>j</sub> and b<sub>j</sub>, being the same as (2), is actually linear. For the n-point interpolation problem, the linear system, of order ∑<sup>n</sup><sub>i=1</sub> r<sub>i</sub>, which might be large, is replaceable by separate linear systems of orders r<sub>i</sub> (or even r<sub>i</sub> + r<sub>i+1</sub> + ⋯ + r<sub>i+j</sub> when conveniently small) by applying the lemma to the continued fraction (3) N(x)/D(x) = a<sub>1,0</sub> + x - x<sub>1</sub>|/|a<sub>1,1</sub> + x - x<sub>1</sub>|/|a<sub>1,2</sub> + ⋯ + x - x<sub>1</sub>|/|a<sub>1,r<sub>1</sub> - 1</sub> + x - x<sub>1</sub>|/|a<sub>2,0</sub> + x - x<sub>2</sub>|/|a<sub>2,1</sub> + ⋯ + x - x<sub>2</sub>|/|a<sub>2,r<sub>2</sub> - 1</sub> + x - x<sub>2</sub>|/|a<sub>3,0</sub> + ⋯ + x - x<sub>n-1</sub>|/|a<sub>n,0</sub> + x - x<sub>n</sub>|/|a<sub>n,1</sub> + ⋯ + x - x<sub>n</sub>|/|a<sub>n,r<sub>n</sub> - 1</sub>. In (3), which has the property (proven in two ways) that the determination of a<sub>i,m</sub> is independent of all a's that follow, we find a<sub>i,m</sub> stepwise, but several at a time (instead of singly which is more tedious), retrieving them readily from the solutions of those lower-order linear systems.
